Detailed Description

Base class for all game players.

This is the basic encapsulation of a game playing entity--it is capable of coming up with a move, having that move acted upon by Game::Play, and then dealing with the results of that interaction. Anything useful is done by derived classes of this base.

Member Typedef Documentation

typedef wxMap< Player * , wxString > Player::MoveMap [protected]

A map which associates Player pointers with strings.

This map associates an individual competing player object (determined by address) with a list of moves that player has taken in the past, stored as a wxString.

Member Function Documentation

void Player::AddPayoff ( const Player *  opponent,
char  opponentsMove,
int  payoff 
)

Register the result of a game interaction.

This function accumulates the pastGames buffer as well as handling keeping score. Once again, only the address of the opponent parameter should be used.

Parameters:
opponentThe opponent against which the score was obtained
opponentsMoveThe move the opponent took this game
payoffThe score this player received this game
virtual Player* Player::Clone ( ) const [pure virtual]

Create a newly allocated copy of the current player.

To properly implement an "add player" event (wxEVT_ADD_PLAYER), we need to be able to create an arbitrary copy of a given player, without knowing its type at runtime. This method returns an exact duplicate of the current object, and is simply implemented as return new [Type](*this);.

Returns:
A copy of the current player

Implemented in FSAPlayer, RandomPlayer, and TitForTatPlayer.

static int Player::GenerateID ( ) [static]

Generate an unique player ID.

To permit adding multiple players of the same type to tournaments, players need to be referred to by unique identification numbers in tournament code. This function generates a unique player ID by incrementing a static counter.

Returns:
A unique player identifier

virtual void Player::Reset ( ) [virtual]

Reset the player state.

This function is called before the Match class starts a new match, giving the Player a chance to reset all its internal data to prepare for a new game. After this function is called, the Player must forget all previous interaction it has had with any other players, and must also have a score of zero.

Reimplemented in FSAPlayer.

virtual bool Player::Think ( const Game *  gamePlayed,
const Player *  nextOpponent 
) [pure virtual]

Determine the next game move.

This function sets nextMove based upon some function of pastGames[&nextOpponent].

Note:
The behavior of the Think function should not depend on anything but the identity (i.e. address) of nextOpponent -- in particular, cheating (reading the value of nextOpponent->nextMove, that is) will do you no good, because you have no guarantee whether or not nextOpponent has had its Think function called already.
Parameters:
gamePlayedThe game currently being played
nextOpponentThe opponent which is currently being played
Returns:
True if move was made successfully, false otherwise

Implemented in FSAPlayer, RandomPlayer, and TitForTatPlayer.

Member Data Documentation

int Player::id [protected]

This player's unique identifier.

This value is an identifier unique to this execution of Oyun, used to tell the difference between players in a tournament.

wxChar Player::nextMove

The move the player will take in the next game turn.

This value is set by Think and should not be relied upon before Think is called.

MoveMap Player::opponentMoves [protected]

Storage for past player interactions.

A collection of all opponents this player has faced and the moves that those players have taken. Serves as "memory" for more complicated players (like tit-for-tat), which respond to the actions of others.

int Player::score [protected]

This player's score for this game.

This value accumulates over the course of a Match (which consists of many repeated games).
